summary:
Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Paul Merson has continued his feud with Andros Townsend, criticizing his late substitution for Tottenham against Burnley. Merson had previously written that Townsend shouldn't have been in the England squad, but was proven wrong when Townsend scored against Italy. Townsend had responded to Merson's criticism after scoring, but Merson has continued to taunt him on Twitter, unable to resist having another dig after Townsend's late appearance for Tottenham.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Chelsea has made a formal offer for FC Tokyo's 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto, according to FC Tokyo president Naoki Ogane. Muto would join Chelsea's partner club Vitesse Arnhem on loan if the move is completed. The deal is reportedly worth £4million, but Muto has not yet decided to join Chelsea. Muto is a Japan international with 11 caps and has played for FC Tokyo since 2013. Chelsea's interest in Muto is claimed to be unrelated to their £200million sponsorship deal with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

A large-scale study found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be overweight or obese as toddlers. The study, which analyzed data from over 12,000 healthy two-year-olds, found that repeated antibiotic prescriptions before the age of two increased the likelihood of being overweight. Boys were particularly prone to weight gain after being given antibiotics and were also slightly taller than those who hadn't received the drugs. The researchers suggested that antibiotics may cause weight gain by killing off gut bugs that normally feed on food, freeing up more energy for the body, and potentially increasing appetite. The study's findings highlight the importance of judicious antibiotic use in infancy, as the worldwide childhood obesity epidemic continues to grow.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard ceremony, in front of hundreds of tourists. The incident was caught on camera by a tourist, David Meadwell. The guard lost his footing, slid sideways, and dropped his rifle, but quickly scrambled to his feet. The guard is believed to have slipped due to the metal protectors on his boots. The incident occurred during a ceremony that takes place daily in the summer and every other day in winter, and is watched by thousands of tourists. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment on the incident.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

A&E networks is remaking the epic miniseries "Roots" about an African-American slave, Kunta Kinte, and his descendants. The original aired in 1977 and had over 100 million viewers. The new version will air in 2016 on A&E, Lifetime, and History, and will be more faithful to Alex Haley's novel. LeVar Burton, who played Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce. The remake aims to bring the story to a new generation, with added authenticity from historical scholars. The new "Roots" will be released in a different social context, with a new generation having witnessed significant events such as Barack Obama's presidency and the Oscar win for "12 Years a Slave".

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

A former royal footman, Christopher Lawler, has alleged that he was forced into an orgy by palace aides at Clarence House in 1978. On his first day, he was groped and pinned to a chair by a male staff member. Lawler, now 64, reported the incident to the palace, but was ignored for months before the police were notified. The incident allegedly occurred when Lawler walked into a bedroom to look for a pen and was accosted by two men. He was threatened to keep quiet and left the job immediately. Lawler, a former police officer, was "haunted" by the incident and only reported it again last year after hearing about a probe into historical child abuse cases. The police are now investigating the claims, and a retired royal aide was interviewed but denied involvement. The Royal Household has stated that it will cooperate with the police probe.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information:

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced they are expecting a child in a rap video set to the theme song of 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air.' The video, which has been viewed over 1.7 million times on YouTube, features the couple rapping about their journey to pregnancy. They reveal that they conceived within two months and share a sonogram of their unborn child at the end of the video. The video was made so loved ones living far away could know about the baby, and its success was unexpected. The couple may make another video after finding out the gender of the child.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film Gone With the Wind was sold at auction for $137,000. The dress, a gray jacket and skirt ensemble with a black zigzag applique, was worn in key scenes, including when Scarlett meets Rhett Butler. Originally slate blue-gray, the dress has faded to light gray over time. It was part of a collection of over 300,000 pieces of memorabilia amassed by James Tumblin, who acquired it for $20 in the 1960s. The auction, held by Heritage Auctions in Beverly Hills, featured over 150 items from the film, including other notable items such as a straw hat worn by Leigh ($52,500) and a suit worn by Clark Gable ($55,000). The sale highlighted the film's significance, which celebrated its 75th anniversary and was based on Margaret Mitchell's 1936 best-selling book.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

A 2-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo on Saturday when his mother, who was holding him and another child, lost her grip, causing him to slip and fall 10-12ft into the pit. The boy was rescued by his parents before emergency services arrived and was taken to MetroHealth Medical Center with minor bruises and bumps, including a leg injury. Fortunately, the cheetahs did not attack him. The zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the parents on Monday, citing eyewitness accounts that suggest the child was dangled over the railing. The exhibit was closed following the incident.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

A speed camera on Wellington Road in Handsworth, Birmingham, has been repositioned to point at a residential house. Although it was previously used to enforce the 30mph speed limit, it has been non-functional since 2013 when around 300 outdated speed cameras in the West Midlands were decommissioned. The camera's reorientation is shrouded in mystery, but Birmingham City Council is aware and plans to take action, potentially removing it. The council is developing a new pilot using digital technology, but the camera in question is not part of it.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Usain Bolt will compete for Jamaica at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3. Bolt stated that he is "fit, healthy and ready to run" and expressed his desire to make Jamaica proud. The Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association (JAAA) announced his participation, with General Secretary Garth Gayle expecting "sprint magic" from Bolt. The full Jamaican team will be announced shortly.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Neymar and his Barcelona teammate Dani Alves supported the club's basketball team by watching their Euro League match against Real Madrid, which Barcelona won 85-80. The duo were accompanied by Neymar's sister Rafaella. Prior to this, Barcelona had won their La Liga El Clasico match, and Neymar had helped Brazil beat Chile 1-0 in an international friendly, withstanding several tough challenges. Barcelona will return to La Liga action on Sunday to take on Celta Vigo as they continue their pursuit of a treble.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Italy is experiencing a surge in migrants from Africa and the Middle East attempting to reach Europe. Between Friday and Monday, 8,480 migrants were rescued by the Italian coast guard, which received 20 SOS calls on Monday alone. There are concerns that 400 migrants may be missing after a ship carrying 550 people reportedly capsized off the Libyan coast, although the Italian coast guard has not confirmed this. The International Organization for Migration reported that over 10,000 migrants arrived in Italy in the first three months of 2015, mostly from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, with at least 480 dying during the crossing due to bad weather and overcrowding.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Arsene Wenger is pleased that Alexis Sanchez chose Arsenal over Liverpool, although he is unsure of the exact reason for Sanchez's decision. Wenger acknowledges that Liverpool's interest in Sanchez may have been used as leverage in negotiations over Luis Suarez's transfer to Barcelona. Sanchez has made a significant impact at Arsenal, scoring 19 goals, and Wenger praises his qualities, work-rate, and adaptability. Wenger also comments on Liverpool's progress under Brendan Rodgers, despite losing Suarez and Daniel Sturridge to injury, and dismisses speculation linking him to signing Liverpool's Raheem Sterling.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Sir Bradley Wiggins will attempt to break the cycling hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome (Lee Valley VeloPark). The current record is 52.491km, set by Australian Rohan Dennis in February. Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will ride in front of a capacity crowd of 6,000, with tickets available from April 19. The event will be broadcast live on Sky Sports. Wiggins is expected to set a mark that will last for some time and is also targeting a British record eighth Olympic medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Serena Williams beat Sara Errani 4-6 7-6(3) 6-3 in a Fed Cup play-off, improving her record against Errani to 8-0. However, the US team was relegated to World Group II after losing the doubles rubber 6-0 6-3. Williams described the match as an "eye-opener", stating she was not as ready for the claycourt season as she thought. The US captain, Mary Joe Fernandez, acknowledged the team's defeat and vowed to work harder to get back into the World Group.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

River Plate is interested in signing Manchester United striker Radamel Falcao and has expressed openness to the possibility. Falcao spent 8 years with River Plate before leaving in 2009 and has a history of success with the club, scoring 34 goals in 90 appearances. The deal is considered complicated, and Falcao's future is uncertain as Manchester United may not exercise their option to keep him. Recently, Falcao has scored 3 goals in 2 games for Colombia, equaling the country's all-time goalscoring record.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Ella Henderson, a 19-year-old X Factor finalist and pop star, has partnered with dry shampoo brand Batiste as the face of their 2015 'Ready For It' campaign. This is her first brand collaboration. The campaign features Henderson showcasing various hairstyles against a blurred city background, and includes a TV advertising campaign with her single "Mirror Man". Henderson expressed excitement about working with Batiste, a product she uses regularly. The partnership was facilitated by the MILES agency, and her management team, Crown Talent & Media Group, welcomed the collaboration, citing the natural synergy between the artist and the brand.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

A billboard featuring Kenosha police officer Pablo Torres, who fatally shot 26-year-old Aaron Siler on March 14, has been erected in Kenosha, Wisconsin, sparking outrage among Siler's family and friends. The billboard, paid for by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, thanks the community for its support. Siler was shot after arming himself with a weapon during a vehicle and foot pursuit with Torres, who was responding to an active felony probation and parole warrant. Torres is currently on leave pending the outcome of the investigation into the shooting. The family and friends of Siler have called the billboard "disrespectful" and are asking for it to be taken down, with one friend stating that it felt like the billboard was saying "thank you for killing Aaron." The police association claims that no offense was intended and that the billboard was simply to thank the community for its support. The investigation into Siler's death is ongoing.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the Iran-Pakistan border. Three militants were killed, and the Jaish al Adal militant group claimed responsibility. The group, which is based in Pakistan's Balochistan province, has previously targeted Shiites and Iranian territory. Iranian officials have asked Pakistan to apprehend the surviving assailants, criticizing Pakistan for failing to rein in the terrorists. Pakistan has condemned the attack as "an act of terrorism" and stated that it will investigate and bring the perpetrators to justice if they are found to have entered Pakistan.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Japan's Defense Minister, Gen Nakatani, told the country's parliament that the Air Self Defense Force (ASDF) has never encountered an extraterrestrial unidentified flying object (UFO). The statement was made in response to a query from lawmaker Antonio Inoki, a former wrestler who claims to have seen a UFO. Nakatani explained that the ASDF scrambles fighter jets to investigate unidentified flying objects, but they have always turned out to be earthly objects, such as birds. Inoki's question was part of a lighthearted exchange, but it touched on a topic that has been discussed by Japanese politicians before, including in 2007 when then-Defense Minister Shigeru Ishiba considered the legal implications of defending against an alien invasion.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

A 35-year-old passenger, Jin Pai, was hospitalised with deep cuts on his leg and buttocks after a toilet he was using collapsed at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in China. Jin Pai had been standing on the toilet rim to avoid touching the seat, which he thought might be unclean, when it gave way and shattered. He called his travel companions for help, as he was too embarrassed to shout, and was subsequently taken to hospital where he received dozens of stitches. Initially, Jin Pai admitted to his friends that he was squatting on the toilet, but later changed his story to the police, claiming he was sitting when the toilet collapsed, possibly to avoid compensation. Authorities deemed the incident an accident and reminded users to use toilets as intended.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Kevin Rebbie, 56, of Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested for allegedly sexually abusing a 15-year-old girl in her home over a four-year period and filming her and others with a hidden camera in the bathroom. The girl discovered the camera in March and told investigators that Rebbie had been watching and molesting her since she was 9 years old. Investigators found 41 videos on the camera, including 34 that showed victims showering, and Rebbie admitted to filming several victims. He faces charges including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, and invasion of privacy, and is being held on $500,000 bail. His preliminary hearing is on May 1.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama has created a series of unusual father-daughter portraits, where daughters stand still and smile while their fathers leap into the air, often in dramatic poses. The images are part of Aoyama's book, "Daughter and Salary Man", which features the fathers wearing sharp suits and the daughters in casual clothing, posing in front of Japanese landmarks. The photographs aim to capture the fathers' fun and playful side, with some older fathers displaying pained expressions during their energetic jumps. The series has garnered significant online interest due to its unique and quirky nature.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

The dismissal of Paul Downton as England's managing director has paved the way for Kevin Pietersen's potential return to the England team. Pietersen, who was axed by Downton in 2014, has rejoined Surrey and is attempting to force his way back into the Test set-up. Pietersen was seen posing for Surrey's team photo, displaying a range of emotions, before the start of the County Championship season. Surrey is set to begin their campaign on April 19 against Glamorgan, with Pietersen hoping to impress and earn a recall to the England team ahead of the upcoming Ashes series.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, a relegation-threatened Romanian club, has sacked Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week due to a poor run, including a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani. Ze Maria was initially fired on Wednesday, reinstated on Thursday, and then fired again on Saturday. He will be replaced by Serbian coach Vanya Radinovic.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Radamel Falcao's former Monaco teammate Nabil Dirar believes Falcao regrets leaving Monaco for Manchester United on loan. Falcao has struggled at United, scoring only 4 goals, and is unlikely to be signed permanently for £46m. Dirar thinks Falcao was unhappy in Monaco, but would have been better off staying, playing in the Champions League.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

A man robbed a dairy in Christchurch, New Zealand, wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and a fluoro orange sweatshirt. He is described as being 'very tall'. The robber demanded cash from the owner's daughter, took the till drawer, and made off with around $1500. The incident occurred on Saturday at around 12:30 pm at the Union St dairy. Police are investigating and are appealing to the public for information to identify the suspect, who remains at large.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, has been arrested twice for having inappropriate relationships with 15-year-old students. Initially, she was arrested on March 19 for allowing a student to touch her breasts and kissing him, and was released on bail. A second student came forward, alleging that Granado had sex with him in her car on two consecutive nights in January. Granado was arrested again on Monday and released on $50,000 bail. She has been suspended from teaching and put on administrative leave by school officials.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

A video showing a large crocodile swimming through a public marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead dog in its jaws, has been viewed over 500,000 times online. The dog belonged to a local bike shop owner and was likely killed after approaching the crocodile out of curiosity. The incident was witnessed by New Zealander Tim Weston, who was on holiday with his wife. Crocodiles are common in Puerto Vallarta, which is built among mangroves that are their natural habitat, and are often spotted in the area, including on the resort's golf course. The 'American Crocodiles' in Mexico can grow up to 6 meters in length and are increasingly living near humans due to urbanisation.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Hull City manager Steve Bruce remains confident that his team can avoid relegation from the Premier League despite a 2-0 loss to Southampton, which left them just two points clear of the drop zone. Bruce initially targeted 10 wins to survive but now believes "nine or eight might be enough." Hull have six games remaining, including tough fixtures against top teams. Bruce attributes their struggles to long-term injuries to key players, including Michael Dawson, Nikica Jelavic, and Robert Snodgrass. Despite the challenges, Bruce is "sure and convinced" that his team can stay up.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Ian Guffick, a 31-year-old teacher at Mitton Manor Primary School, allowed pupils to alter their SATs exam answers after the test session had finished, and also made changes himself. An investigation by the local education authority found that exam rules had been breached, resulting in the Department for Education annulling the entire school's SATs results. Guffick admitted to the allegations and was forced to resign. A conduct panel found his actions to be dishonest, but not fraudulent, and he was banned from teaching for at least two years. Guffick was given 28 days to appeal the decision to the High Court.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Anders Lindegaard, Manchester United's third-choice goalkeeper, has been enjoying his personal life despite struggling for playing time. He is married to Swedish model Misse Beqiri, whom he tied the knot with in a beach wedding in Mauritius last year. The couple has a son together and have been dating since 2012. Lindegaard posted a photo with Beqiri on his Instagram, referencing her as his "sunshine". Beqiri has Albanian roots and regularly posts modelling photos on her Instagram page, which has over 17,000 followers. Lindegaard has made just 19 league appearances in five seasons at Manchester United, with David de Gea and Victor Valdes ahead of him in the goalkeeper pecking order, and has been told he can leave the club.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

The 13 glowing blue letters that lit the Bronx above Yankee Stadium were auctioned at Sotheby's but failed to find a buyer, with only a Sotheby's employee making a bid of $260,000. The letters, owned by Yankee Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson since 2008, were estimated to bring in $300,000 to $600,000. Jackson had hoped a new generation would own the Yankees icon. The letters were installed in 1976 and removed in 2008. In the same auction, a 1960s New York Mets bullpen car was sold for $112,500, exceeding its estimated value of $20,000 to $30,000.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers has spoken to Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe about their professional responsibilities after they were involved in two incidents: Sterling inhaling nitrous oxide and both being pictured with shisha pipes. Neither player will be disciplined, but Rodgers has urged them to learn from the incidents. The team is preparing for the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, with Steven Gerrard available after a suspension, and Rodgers' priority is to steer Liverpool into their first FA Cup final under his management.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Mesut Ozil returned to London after Germany's Euro 2016 qualifier win over Georgia and posted a picture on Twitter relaxing with his dog. He is expected to start for Arsenal against Liverpool at the Emirates Stadium after missing the previous game against Newcastle due to illness. Ozil has been in fine form since returning from injury, with 4 assists and 3 goals, and claims to have adjusted to English football, appreciating the demanding schedule.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Barcelona president Josep Maria Bartomeu has stated that the club is "very happy" with manager Luis Enrique and has no plans to replace him, despite speculation. Enrique, who signed a two-year deal last summer, is on track to win La Liga and has impressed during his tenure. Bartomeu emphasized that Enrique has a contract until 2016 and is focused on the current season, with Barcelona still in contention for three trophies. The team recently defeated Valencia 2-0, with goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Liverpool's vice-captain Jordan Henderson has agreed to a new long-term contract with the club, worth around £100,000 per week, running until 2020. The 24-year-old England international has been a key player under Brendan Rodgers, contributing 7 goals and 13 assists this season. Henderson is expected to replace Steven Gerrard as club captain when Gerrard leaves for LA Galaxy this summer. The deal is the third contract extension for a key player in Rodgers' squad, following Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Filipe Luis wants to stay at Chelsea until the end of his contract, despite Atletico Madrid's interest in re-signing him. Luis has struggled to secure the left-back position at Chelsea since joining last July. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is keeping his team focused on the Premier League title run-in, with nine difficult games ahead.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Nathan Hughes, a Wasps rugby player, had his 3-match ban overturned on appeal after being suspended for accidentally knocking out George North with his knee during a match on March 27. Hughes was initially given a red card and banned for 3 weeks for being "reckless", despite no intent being found. The ban was met with widespread criticism, with many, including Wasps players and former England player Austin Healey, calling it a "joke". The appeal panel ultimately ruled that no act of foul play took place, as the incident was deemed accidental, and rescinded the ban, allowing Hughes to return to action immediately.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Wildfires in southeastern Siberia, caused by farmers burning grass, spread out of control due to strong winds, destroying dozens of villages. The smoke was carried by atmospheric winds across the Pacific Ocean to the Pacific Northwest, resulting in intense red sunsets in parts of Oregon, Washington, and British Columbia. The red color is due to smoke particles filtering out shorter wavelength colors, allowing red and orange to penetrate the air unfiltered. As the smoke dissipates, air quality will improve and the sunsets will lose their reddish hue.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Becky Schoenig's brand new 2015 Ford Fusion was stolen from her driveway in St. Louis, Missouri. The car was later found and returned to her with modifications, including red rims and detailing, and orange accents on the steering wheel. Instead of being upset, Schoenig joked about the changes on Facebook, thanking the thieves for "pimping out" her car. However, she did reveal that the car had a strong smell of cigarettes and marijuana, and is having it professionally cleaned. She is also creating a smoothie to honor the man who found her car, Mick Sexton.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Manchester City players, including Sergio Aguero, David Silva, and Yaya Toure, stand to lose £500,000 each in bonuses if the team fails to qualify for the Champions League this season. The total amount at stake for the squad is around £12 million. City are currently in fourth place, but face a tight finish to the season, with rivals Liverpool closing in. The top three teams qualify automatically for the Champions League, while the fourth-place team must win a qualifying round. Manchester City's manager, Manuel Pellegrini, has admitted that the team has "thrown it into the garbage" in the last three months, and their failure to qualify for the Champions League could also impact their ability to attract top talent, such as Paul Pogba, in the next transfer window.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Manchester United's Under 18s beat Manchester City 1-0 in a 'mini-derby' at Altrincham's Moss Lane, with Callum Gribbin scoring the winning free-kick. The match was a departure from the usual senior derby, with 13 English players and 10 Mancunians on show, and was played in front of a crowd of around 1,000. United's manager, Paul McGuinness, aimed to give his team a more authentic experience by playing in a more senior-style formation. The result leaves United two points behind leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand, while City have lost both matches in the end-of-season play-off series. The match showcased talented young players, highlighting the potential for homegrown talent to break into the first team in the coming years.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

England goalkeeper Joe Hart praised Italian goalkeeper Gianluigi Buffon, calling him a "legend of the game" after Buffon earned his 147th cap. Hart, who earned his 50th cap in the same match, said Buffon is an inspiration and that he is still learning from him. Hart expressed his pride in reaching 50 caps and his desire to continue playing for England and adding to his cap total.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Chipotle, a Mexican restaurant chain, has partnered with the Postmates app to offer delivery services for online and mobile orders in 67 cities. The delivery service will come with a 9% service charge and a delivery fee starting at $5. Chipotle had previously declined collaborations with third-party delivery services but has now teamed up with Postmates, which uses independent contractors to make deliveries. The move is part of a larger trend, with other chains like Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King also exploring delivery options. The partnership is seen as a way for Chipotle to tap into the $70 billion food delivery market.

The parents of Martin Richard, the youngest victim of the Boston Marathon bombings, have written an emotional plea to the Justice Department to consider taking the death penalty off the table for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the convicted bomber. The Richards, whose other child was severely injured in the attack, argue that pursuing the death penalty could lead to years of appeals, prolonging their suffering and painful memories. They support a life sentence without possibility of release in exchange for waiving Tsarnaev's appeal rights, allowing them to "turn the page" and move towards a better future. The sentencing phase of Tsarnaev's trial is set to begin, and is expected to last four weeks.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

A custom-built Boeing 747-8 jumbo jet has been converted into a luxury home for a mystery billionaire at a cost of £400million. The jet, which can normally carry 600 passengers, has been tailored to the owner's specifications over a three-year period and features multiple luxurious amenities, including a dining room, kitchen, lounges, state room, conference room, office, and bedrooms. The plane has eight full beds in the 'aeroloft' on the top deck and can accommodate dozens of guests. The interior is designed to resemble a luxury hotel, with hotel-like ambience and decor, and is far more luxurious than typical first-class commercial flights.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying the uncrewed Dragon cargo spacecraft to the International Space Station (ISS) from Cape Canaveral, Florida. Although the launch was successful, the attempt to land the rocket's first stage on a floating barge was unsuccessful, with the rocket landing too hard and tipping over. The Dragon spacecraft is expected to dock with the ISS in a couple of days, delivering over 4,300 pounds of supplies, and will later return to Earth with science experiments and trash, splashing down in the Pacific Ocean. The mission aims to test reusable rocket technology, with SpaceX hoping to reduce the cost of access to space by a factor of a hundred.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Priscilla Presley is collaborating with NBC's Today show on a contest for an Elvis-obsessed couple to win a wedding at the new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas. The winning couple, to be announced on Monday, will marry on April 23 at the Westgate Hotel, where Elvis performed over 830 shows. Priscilla will serve as a witness, and the couple will receive a wedding reception, hotel suite, airfares, and concert tickets. The chapel is part of a permanent Graceland exhibit and has been designed with Priscilla's input to be "first-class" and not a "joke", with no Elvis impersonators allowed.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his team can catch Manchester City in the Premier League after a 2-0 win over Newcastle United. Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet played their 47th game of the season, equalling a record. Liverpool trailed Manchester City by four points, who had recently lost 4-2 to Manchester United. Raheem Sterling and Joe Allen scored the goals in the win, with Allen netting his first Anfield goal. Henderson stated that his team will "keep going, keep winning" to close the gap with Manchester City.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Roma ended a four-month winless streak at home with a 1-0 victory over Napoli in a key Serie A match, thanks to a Miralem Pjanic goal in the 25th minute and excellent goalkeeping by Morgan de Sanctis. The win moved Roma four points ahead of Lazio in second place, while Napoli's winless streak extended to five matches, leaving them in fifth. The match was played under tight security due to previous incidents between the two teams' fans, but there were no reports of problems.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Doncaster Rovers had a dull League One match against Fleetwood Town, resulting in a 0-0 draw at Keepmoat Stadium. The match was uneventful, and the club's media team struggled to compile highlights, ultimately creating a 27-second video featuring just 14 seconds of match action.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Roland Giroux, a fish owner, has a remarkable bond with his blood parrot cichlid, a hybrid fish bred in Taiwan around 1986. Initially, the fish was not sociable, but after Giroux removed its tankmates that were bullying it and started interacting with it by hand-feeding frozen blood worms, it became more sociable. The fish now enjoys being stroked and massaged by Giroux, who spends at least 15 minutes daily playing with it. The parties have differing stances on renewing the UK's nuclear deterrent, with the Conservatives and UKIP committed to a like-for-like replacement, while Labour, the Liberal Democrats, and others propose alternatives or scrapping it altogether. The UK's new aircraft carriers may also be undermanned and under-equipped, highlighting the risk of a "hollow force" with inadequate personnel to operate its equipment.

The Northern Ireland Assembly is set to approve a motion to pardon gay and bisexual men convicted of now-abolished sexual offences, in line with England and Wales' 'Turing's Law'. The UK's Metropolitan Police barrister, Richard Horwell QC, stated that the Russian state was likely involved in the poisoning of Alexander Litvinenko in 2006. Litvinenko, a former KGB officer who defected to the UK, was poisoned with polonium-210 during a meeting with Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi, who deny any wrongdoing. The inquiry heard that the suspects left a "trail of polonium" and had no credible answer to the scientific evidence against them, but extradition attempts have failed and they remain in Russia. The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 out of 28 governor posts in Nigeria's recent elections, marking a significant defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP). Both Olam and Temasek reject the allegations, with Olam releasing the names of its 14 suppliers and stating that it will remove non-compliant producers from its supply chain. The palm oil industry is known for its troubled track record, with accusations of deforestation, labour abuses, and environmental damage. Olam is also facing allegations of bulldozing rainforests in Gabon to establish palm oil plantations, which it denies, stating that its private-public partnerships in the country are "responsible and transparent".

Macedonian President Ivanov cancelled an investigation into government abuse of power revealed by covert recordings, citing a desire to "put an end to the agony" before June elections. Steven Gerrard, 36, is returning to Liverpool as a youth coach in February, his first job since retiring as a player. Ofsted has found evidence of children being taught in squalid conditions in three unregistered schools in Birmingham, which have now been closed. Lilliard Gin is a new gin distillery based at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, Scottish Borders. Gary Green, 51, reversed a vehicle into Harry Whitlam at Swithens Farm, Rothwell, in August 2013, killing him. Suarez's competitive Barcelona debut is likely to be on October 26 against Real Madrid.

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a wife-carrying race, beating Vytautas Kirkliauskas and his wife Neringa. The competition involved a 380-metre obstacle course. The winners will now compete in the World Championships in Finland in July.

The UK government plans to scrap the paper car tax disc system in October 2014 and replace it with an electronic system, allowing monthly direct debit payments. This change may lead to job role changes and potential reductions in staff at the Driving and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA), which has 5,000 workers. Minister Stephen Hammond has assured that any staff reductions will be managed through redeployment to other areas of the business, rather than redundancies. Swansea East AM Mike Hedges has welcomed the minister's assurances, stating that they will "give comfort" to concerned DVLA employees.

Hungarian Foreign Minister Szijjarto stated that the EU should not interfere with Hungary's "domestic issues", referring to laws related to asylum seekers, NGOs, and higher education. * Only 61,000 new apprenticeships are for young people, compared to 570,000 in Germany

* Radically expanding apprenticeships to 300,000 new starts per year
* Prioritizing level three apprenticeships lasting at least three years
* Limiting two-year level two courses to 10% of apprenticeships

He thinks that same-sex marriage should not be a constitutional right and that individual states should decide whether to allow it through a legislative process. Rubio has also said that he would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer, even if he disagrees with their decision, as he would not want to hurt them. Rubio's views on gay marriage are influenced by his Catholic faith, but he has also drawn a parallel between his views on gay marriage and divorce, stating that he would not stop loving someone if they were divorced. Rubio has announced his candidacy for the presidency and has received significant financial backing from donors.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, a Spanish-Latvian couple, embarked on an open-ended cycling journey around the world, with no plans or agenda, after quitting their jobs in Manchester. In 356 days, they covered 7,000 miles across 16 countries, living on less than €3 per day. They keep costs low by camping (161 nights), using hosting websites like Couchsurfing (66 nights) and WarmShowers (44 nights), and relying on kindness from strangers. Their daily expenses are mostly for food, which averages €2.74 per person. They started in London, cycled through Europe, and are now in Armenia, planning to continue into Asia and eventually cycle across the American continent, expecting to be on the road for several years.

England full-back Mike Brown has adopted a cautious approach to recovering from his latest concussion, which he suffered during a match against Italy in February. He is unsure when he will return to action for his club, Harlequins. Brown was knocked out cold during the match and, after initially hoping to recover in time for a subsequent match against Ireland, pulled out due to ongoing symptoms. He credits increased awareness of concussion symptoms, gained through online modules, with helping him make the decision to pull out. Other players, including Northampton's George North and Ireland's Johnny Sexton, have also been sidelined due to concussions, with North being advised not to play again this season and Sexton being stood down for 12 weeks. Brown is taking a staged approach to his recovery and is prioritizing caution to avoid a long-term absence.

Research suggests that the frequency of sex among Britons has declined since the emergence of the internet. A typical heterosexual couple now has sex three times a month, down from four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. Professor David Spiegelhalter, a statistician at Cambridge University, attributes this decline to the increased blurring of boundaries between work, home, and personal life due to technology, such as checking emails at all times. This has resulted in less "quiet time" and a decrease in time spent with partners, causing sex to fall down the list of priorities.

Tibetan Mastiffs, once highly valued in China and selling for up to £1.2 million, have become unpopular due to the government's anti-corruption crackdown and bans on owning dogs over 50kg in several cities. As a result, many are being sent to slaughterhouses for their meat, which is used in cheap hotpots, and their skin for leather belts. Animal welfare workers have rescued dogs being transported to slaughterhouses, finding them in cramped cages without food or water, and some with broken bones. The breed's decline is also attributed to cross-breeding, which damaged the quality of the breed, and urbanization, which has made people realize they are not suited to city living. Hundreds of Tibetan Mastiffs are feared to be meeting a cruel fate, with some being stolen from streets and sold to slaughterhouses, and unscrupulous breeders offloading "imperfect" specimens.

Leeds-based Direct Line ran a competition called #everydayfix, asking groups to design products to solve common everyday problems. A survey of 2,000 people identified the top "everyday emergencies", including not being able to sleep (46%), losing keys (37%), and running out of phone battery (31%). Three prototype products were shortlisted: "Snooze", an alarm clock that silences phone notifications; "Forget Me Lock", a device that indicates whether the front door is locked; and "Nipper", a portable phone charger that uses household batteries. The public can vote for their favorite product on Twitter by retweeting with the #everydayfix hashtag, and the winner will be funded through a Kickstarter campaign. The competition was a collaboration between Direct Line and London-based design company Makerversity.

A large-scale study found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be overweight or obese as toddlers. The study, which analyzed data from over 12,000 healthy two-year-olds, found that repeated antibiotic prescriptions before the age of two increased the likelihood of being overweight. Boys were particularly prone to weight gain after being given antibiotics and were also slightly taller than those who hadn't received the drugs. The researchers suggested that antibiotics may cause weight gain by killing off gut bugs that normally feed on food, freeing up more energy for the body, and potentially increasing appetite. The study's findings highlight the importance of judicious antibiotic use in infancy, as the worldwide childhood obesity epidemic continues to grow.

The guard is believed to have slipped due to the metal protectors on his boots. On his first day, he was groped and pinned to a chair by a male staff member. Lawler, now 64, reported the incident to the palace, but was ignored for months before the police were notified. The incident allegedly occurred when Lawler walked into a bedroom to look for a pen and was accosted by two men. He was threatened to keep quiet and left the job immediately. Lawler, a former police officer, was "haunted" by the incident and only reported it again last year after hearing about a probe into historical child abuse cases. A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film Gone With the Wind was sold at auction for $137,000. The dress, a gray jacket and skirt ensemble with a black zigzag applique, was worn in key scenes, including when Scarlett meets Rhett Butler. Originally slate blue-gray, the dress has faded to light gray over time. It was part of a collection of over 300,000 pieces of memorabilia amassed by James Tumblin, who acquired it for $20 in the 1960s. The auction, held by Heritage Auctions in Beverly Hills, featured over 150 items from the film, including other notable items such as a straw hat worn by Leigh ($52,500) and a suit worn by Clark Gable ($55,000). He left the National Institute of Health in 1992 to form a private research institute and later founded Celera Genomics, a commercial company that completed the human genome in 2001. Venter's work has been marked by controversy, but he has also achieved significant breakthroughs, including creating the first synthetic life form, Synthia, and conducting a global genetic treasure hunt to sequence marine microbes. His work has the potential to drive an industrial revolution, enabling the production of bio-based products and mitigating environmental damage.

The Sutton Trust report warns that many apprenticeships in England are low-quality and too short, hindering the economy and young people's job prospects. Key findings include:

* Fewer than 200,000 of 520,000 annual apprenticeships are rated level three (equivalent to A-level)
* Only 61,000 new apprenticeships are for young people, compared to 570,000 in Germany
* England's vocational system has 18,000 qualifications, while Germany has 330
* Since 2010, 58% of apprenticeships have been below level three and 75% have been for those over 25
* 11 young people compete for each apprenticeship

The report calls for:

* Radically expanding apprenticeships to 300,000 new starts per year
* Prioritizing level three apprenticeships lasting at least three years
* Limiting two-year level two courses to 10% of apprenticeships

The Department for Education says it is reforming apprenticeships to "drive up standards", while the Association of Colleges agrees that some existing apprenticeships are respected and should be preserved.
